creator: rich@more.net
text:
Tomcat is not recognizing servlets unless the class for the servlet is in the
top of the classes dir in a webapps WEB-INF.  Servlets that are in a jar file in
the lib directory cannot be found (turns up 404 resource unavailable).  This is
also true for servlets that are in a package, and then placed in the classes
directory, since they are in a package they do not sit directly in the classes
directory but down a few directories.  To reproduce the error try to access the
compressionTest servlet that comes as part of the examples webapp.

creator: craig.mcclanahan@sun.com
text:
The example that you cite, plus all of the tests in the unit test suites for 
Tomcat 4.0, plus all of the Watchdog tests, plus many other applications, work 
just fine -- as long as you follow standard Java rules about class placement.

If you have a servlet whose fully qualified class name is a.b.c.MyServlet, it 
*must* be placed in one of the following locations to be recognized by a Java 
class loader:
* In file "/WEB-INF/classes/a/b/c/MyServlet.class".
* In a JAR file under /WEB-INF/lib, with name "a/b/c/MyServlet.class".

If your servlet class is *not* in a package, then it must be located directly 
under "/WEB-INF/classes", or in the top-level directory of a JAR file under 
"/WEB-INF/lib".
